content:
The "Investor Protection Act of 2002" may be cited as the short title. It addresses liability standards in private securities litigation. The "Investor Protection Act of 2002" addresses liability standards in private securities litigation, amending Section 21D(f) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to establish joint and several liability for damages in private actions. Covered persons settling before final judgment are discharged from contribution claims, with a court-ordered bar upon settlement. The "Investor Protection Act of 2002" establishes joint and several liability for damages in private securities litigation. Covered persons settling before final judgment are discharged from contribution claims through a court-ordered bar upon settlement. In cases of joint liability, a covered person can recover contribution from others based on their percentage of responsibility as determined by the court. The statute of limitations for contribution in private actions is 6 months after a final, nonappealable judgment. This subsection does not change the standard for liability under securities laws. The term 'covered person' refers to defendants in private actions under this title. The amendments made by this section establish joint and several liability for damages in private securities litigation, with a focus on outside directors of the issuer. The term 'outside director' is defined by the Commission's rules. Additionally, a conforming amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 is made, and the applicability of these changes to private actions under securities laws is clarified. The Act does not affect or apply to any private action under securities laws initiated before the enactment date. SEC. 3. PERSONS WHO AID AND ABET VIOLATIONS.

Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to change the standard from "knowingly" to "recklessly" for aiding and abetting violations. It also states that anyone who recklessly assists in a violation will be considered in violation themselves.

SEC. 4. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS.

Adds a new section to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 regarding the statute of limitations for violations. SEC. 37. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS. An implied private right of action under this title must be brought within 5 years of the violation or 3 years of discovery. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF CERTAIN CLASS ACTION LIMITATIONS. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF CERTAIN CLASS ACTION LIMITATIONS. Amends Section 28 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Section 16 of the Securities Act of 1933 to provide additional rights and remedies without limitations.
